name: Huimin 83
title: Huimin 83
overview:
Occupying a prominent corner site opposite Taichung’s National Theatre, this pavilion serves as a marketing suite for the promotion of new residential developments. However, Pao Huei recognises the site’s cultural significance and has envisioned the building as a venue for public events, thereby enhancing the civic life of the city.

Designed as a standalone structure, the building contrasts deliberately with its taller urban surroundings. It is conceived as a flower on the forest floor—visually delicate yet distinctive and intended to be appreciated both at street level and from above as a subtle landmark in the cityscape.

A refined structural frame envelops the pavilion, presenting it as a singular ‘wrapped’ volume over four floors. Within this expressive framework lies a restrained, elegant core containing apartment display spaces. These are framed by two principal areas. At ground level, a reception space merges interior and exterior conditions, drawing in the landscape and guiding visitors along a formal promenade from the street. At the top of the building, a multifunctional, acoustically tuned performance hall sits beneath the apex of the frame, top-lit and offering a grand balcony with views toward the National Theatre.

A daylit staircase forms a central spine, rising through the building and visible from the main entrance. It connects all levels and emphasises the building’s formal organisation.

Internally, the pavilion is lined throughout with veneered timber panels, selected for both acoustic performance and aesthetic consistency. This continuous material treatment lends the interior the character of a finely crafted object—both warm and precise. Together, the structure and its envelope create an architecture of refined presence: modest in scale yet resonant in expression, a civic flower rooted in the cultural landscape of Taichung.
